entry.title: Configure Value Mapping. APP eDocument for a non-localized country CE2508
entry.content:
Hello community,

For non-localized countries in SAP Cloud Public Edition, we found these applications in the documentation: Configure Value Mapping. However, for non-localized countries (Central America), we don't have the option to create the namespace for that country; /EDOXX (where XX is the country). The country isn't available in the list.

With extensibility, which BAdI should be implemented or in which application should this namespace be created?

entry.title: Re: Problems faced while using my SAP BTP Trial Account
entry.content:
Hi Peter,

Thanks for providing the necessary information. I logged-in just to update my comments with same observations regarding problem #1, after searching more online.

Problem 2 however resolved itself so it might be a temporary issue, as previously I had re-booted my device after uninstalling and installing Eclipse again.

In my case "Create" button was disabled for both OData versions with or without draft. After problem 2 resolved itself, I could see a warning in V4 Service binding that it will be read-only if draft mode is not enabled.

Once again thanks for your help. I have accepted your answer.

PS - I also enabled BAS in my trial account and tried to do a Full Stack ABAP App. At the beginning itself, I was asked for a package and a transport. I created a TR using ADT and then referred the same. Is this the right approach?

Regards

Abhijit Moholkar

entry.title: Re: How to handle empty Profit Centers during Realignment...
entry.content:
Realignment should be able to handle profit center empty, but profit center value will not substituted as the target fields for realignment and GRPL are seven GR fields in ACDOCA. 
Please try to implement note 3436316 - Realignment: restriction of profit center does not work as expected to see whether realignment works with profit center empty.

entry.title: Re: My sales order VA01 transaction timed out
entry.content: Thanks for the detailed answer. I have also a proposed solution of looping a maximum of 5 times. DO 5 times. Then I clear vbak and exit the loop. Will this help? Aside from that, my other question is the root cause. Is there something wrong with the data? Sold to party? Ship to party? Material number? Is there something missing or wrong with the sales document itself? Why did it not save in table VBAK? By the way the variable d_bapiso was populated from VBAK-VBELN. If there is a long running job in the background will it affect the saving to table VBAK? Hope you guys shed more light on this one. Thanks Newguy_cloud

entry.title: SAP BTP Neo Environment: Problem calling iflow from SAP Fiori
entry.content:
Hi everyone
I developed an application in SAPUI5 in a Neo environment. Running the application from SAP Web IDE Full-Stack (version: 201119) works correctly, but when deploying it to SAP Fiori, I receive a 405 error.

SAP Web Ide full

 

It is evident from sap fiori that it returns status 405

It uses a destination with an OAuth2ClientCredentials, and neo-app.json and manifest.json are configured for destinations.

 

Any suggestions on how to resolve this error?

entry.title: Why does the FRUN need the Introscope Enterprise Manager?
entry.content:
Hello SAP, 

We are upgrading FRUN 4.0 to FRUN 5.0 , as per the RACI sheet "note DIGITS - Introscope 10.8 Release Notes" says to install Introscope 10.8. But in our system we do not have Introscope installed, given the logs for installation patch of Introscope. 

Best regards,


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Why does the FRUN need the Introscope Enterprise Mana...
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

To ensure performance data collection for non-ABAP managed systems within your network, such as JAVA, BOE, DS, Tomcat, SAP Convergent Charging, and similar products, it is necessary to install one CA Introscope EM per customer network.

This installation is mandatory to enable monitoring and data collection for these systems in FRUN. If these products are present in your environment, please proceed with the installation to facilitate seamless system monitoring.

Please see:

  • Preparing CA APM Enterprise Manager
  • 797147 - Introscope Installation for SAP Customers
  • 3247270 - Introscope 10.8 Release Notes

Best regards,
Vera Jiang

entry.title: Re: Why Can a Contract with Blocked Status in the Source...
entry.content: Hello, Thank you very much for your detailed response. It turns out that I had overlooked the fact that the delivery date of the purchase requisition must fall within the validity period of the source list. The test material I was using has a long procurement lead time, which caused the delivery date to fall outside the valid period in the source list. I’ll also include the additional points you mentioned in my next round of testing and update the configurations accordingly. Thanks again for your helpful insights!

entry.title: LMDB issue for all Web dispatchers after FRUN upgrade
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We have recently upgraded SAP Focused Run system to 5.0 FP01 and after upgrade we observed that for system type SAP Web dispatcher all entries have turned red in data completeness check in LMDB.

Entity type: Technical system

Display Name: Installed Kernel Component

Supplier Name: WebDispatcherInstanceKernel

Please advise. Thanks,

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: LMDB issue for all Web dispatchers after FRUN upgrade
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

Since FRUN 5.0, after implementing Note 3628411 - Enhancement of SAP Web Dispatcher Data Supplier Completeness Checks, the LMDB now provides enhanced support for detailed data supplier checks specific to SAP Web Dispatcher.

To send the missing data supplier WebDispatcherInstanceKernel, please follow the steps outlined in Prepare SAP Web Dispatcher. These steps will guide you through the process to ensure the required data supplier is correctly configured and sent.

Best regards,
Vera Jiang

Hi @RyanMuller,

You are right, I have a very similar situation.

The successor apps and catalogs also did not show up in my system. Our landscape is also a 2-system landscape, and we cannot select that scope item either.

I looked into this issue, and I found out that "Activate Features" is needed. However, I have never done it before, so I didn't know the steps.

But while I was doing the research, I found something. I think the new scope item 7MI might be available only in Germany and the U.S. now.
When you open the "Manage Your Solution" Fiori app and go to "View Solution Scope," you can select the scope item, and it takes you to SAP for Me. I was checking the deprecated and new scope items there. Because 7MI seems to have only a few available countries, I concluded that it is not available in my environment yet.

For now, the deprecated app still works, so I was planning to wait and see if SAP would make it available later. If there's an issue with our environments (yours as well as mine), please let me know.

Best regards,
Ryoma

entry.title: Re: How to Trigger notification to HR team after all Onb...
entry.content:
Hi @Gopinath,

Here’s my approach so far:

  • Created an Email Category using the Onboarding Content Builder and set the Recipient Builder as Onboarding Role-Based Recipient Builder.
  • Created an Email Trigger using the email category created earlier.
  • Created an Email Template linked to both the email category and trigger.
  • Created a Business Rule where the IF condition includes all the tasks that need to be completed, including custom MDF objects like the Super and Tax forms. Added a condition in the business rule to trigger the email template once all the tasks are completed.

Despite this setup, I’m not receiving the notification email after completing all the steps.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur
entry.content:
This sixth post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur. For SAP Customer Experience, look at the new AI agents and the capability to build custom agents, plus AI innovations for marketeers in SAP Emarsys, and Joule and Ai order summaries in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2.  SAP Concur takes travel planning to the next level with the whole new travel experience, complemented by the new Joule Booking Agent enabling users to use natural language to book a trip.

Before reading this, do read the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services, along with links to all the published parts of this blog post series:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 

SAP Customer Experience

The user experience highlights I have picked are all AI-related:

  • AI Agents.
  • SAP Emarsys UX innovations.
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 UX innovations.

This news article summarizes what’s new overall for SAP Customer Experience, beyond UX-related innovations:

  • Connected for Growth: What’s New with SAP Customer Experience in Q2 2025.

AI Agents

As I explained in part 1 of this series, AI agents work in the background to give a greatly enhanced user experience. A number of powerful AI agents are available for SAP Customer Experience, via the package Joule Premium for Customer Experience. This blog post and video give a nice overview of three of them in action:

  • AI Agents in Action.
  • Video: See How AI Agents Streamline Customer Service (3:11 min.)

The latest UX innovations are:

  • Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant.
  • Digital Service Agent (via Early Adopter Care program).
  • Ability to create custom agents in the CX AI Toolkit.

AI Shopping Agent for the SAP Commerce Cloud Shopping Assistant

The shopping agent helps customers when visiting an online shop: they can simply use natural language to state what they are looking for, and the shopping agent will respond with suitable suggestions. Figure 1 shows an example, where the user starts out by stating that they are looking for shoes to wear for two mile long walks while wearing a suit. Two shoes are suggested, and the user asks which one is comfortable right away, since he doesn’t want a long break in period. The agent recommends one model, and the customer then asks for a recommendation for a belt to match, which the agent promptly gives him.

Figure 1: Shopping Agent for the Shopping Assistant from SAP Commerce Cloud. Alt Text: three screenshots of a tall and narrow screen showing a chat, one for each of the interactions explained in the main text. Each response shows one or two images: in the first case two shoes, then one shoe and then one men’s belt.

Find out more here, and watch the video embedded there to see it in action:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Shopping Agent

Digital Service Agent

The new digital service agent helps to provide your customers with a great user experience, similar to how the shopping agent is aimed primarily at your customers. It enables customers to ask questions with natural language and provides answers based on your company’s business knowledge residing in the SAP system. Hence, it is able to resolve common inquiries and issues, giving customers a good experience. Furthermore, by freeing up you sales and service team to focus on more complex inquiries, your customers will also receive a better service and hence better experience.

The digital serice agent is currently only available for select customers via the Early Adopter Care program. Figure 2 in the next section shows how these customers can select it in the AI Agent Builder.

Find out more here:

  • SAP Discovery Center: Digital Service Agent.

Create Custom Agents with CX AI Toolkit

You can now create your own custom agents with the CX AI toolkit. Figure 2 shows the start screen for the AI Agent Builder, where you can select “Custom Tool” to start the wizard which takes you through the steps to create a custom agent.

Figure 2: The AI Agent Builder in the CX AI Tookit for creating custom AI agents or using SAP templates to create AI agents. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Let’s Create AI Agents” in large text in the middle below an illustration, below in much smaller text “Start by selecting an Agent Template”. Below that, two rows of three cards representing Agent Templates are shown: Custom Tool, Knowledge Agent, Classification Agent, Digital Service Agent, Q/A Agent, and Shopping Assistant Agent.

Find out more here:

  • Documentation: Create a Custom AI Agent.

Further Information on AI Agents for SAP Customer Experience

For a deeper understanding of the power of these AI agents, have a look at this longer video:

  • Video: SAP CX AI Toolkit: AI Insights Agents for SAP C4C & Shopping Assistant | Product Inspiration Series (32:21 min.)

SAP Emarsys

AI-Assisted Report Builder using Natural Language

You can now easily create a report using natural language to describe what you are interested in. Figure 3 shows an example of the entry screen. At the bottom you see hints on what kind of queries you can enter.

Figure 3: AI-assisted report builder in SAP Emarsys. Alt Text: A screenshot with “Unlock the Power of Data with the AI-assisted Report Builder” in the middle. At the top a text entry field containing the query “What are the Sent, Delivered, Bounced, Opened, Clicked, Purchased, Unsubscribed, Complained for my Email campaigns in the past month?”, to the right an AI button “Generate Report”. At the bottom of the screen two example queries are listed.

Once you have created the report, you can easily adjust it using a set of convenient filters, such as the date range as well as the list of campaigns and metrics. Watch this video to see it in action:

  • Video: AI-assisted Report Builder (46 seconds).

AI-assisted Product Finder using Natural Language (Pilot)

Pilot customers can now try out the new AI-assisted product finder, which allows users to search for product to add to marketing campaigns using natural language. Figure 4 shows an example of how to enter your search text, see more here:

  • Video: AI-assisted Product Finder (38 seconds).

Figure 4: AI-assisted product finder available to SAP Emarsys pilot customers. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a screen with a left half containing the Product Finder, with a search field containing “Most popular shoes in the last 6 month”, above an empty space with the text “Welcome to Product Finder!” in the middle. The right half shows an image of someone dancing in the sun and an image of a dress, along with some describing text.

Read more about latest SAP Emarsys innovations here:

  • SAP Emarsys Q2 2025 Product Release.
  • SAP Emarsys introduces new generative AI capabilities in June Product Release

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Joule in SAP Sales Cloud

Joule is now available in SAP Sale Cloud Verion 2, helping users get quick insights, for example about an account. As you can see in Figure 5, these insights can be charts as well as text based.

Figure 5: Joule for SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot of Joule showing Customer Account Overview, with the text “Show Key Metrics” entered as chat, below which a card with a vertical stacked bar chart shows credit limit usage (remaining amount and exposure amount), below that a card showing Key Metrics (Activity) and part of a donut chart for Tasks, Phone Calls, Appointments, Visits etc.

Have a deeper look here:

  • Video: Intelligent Selling with Joule in SAP Sales Cloud & SAP S/4HANA Cloud | Product Inspiration Series (16:04 min.)

Sales Order Summary

The Sales Order Summary uses generative AI to summarize key information about the sales order, as well as including information about some changes, for example how the price compares to the original price. Figure 6 shows an example, with the insights shown on the left of the screen.

Figure 6: Sales Order Summary in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a sales order, with the left third showing an overview with AI-generated insights such as “13 days past requested date”, “Overall discount is EUR 808.55”. On the right, the Order Summary tab is shown, with account name, net and gross value, pricing stats, above “Products in Cart (2)” showing a list of two products, followed by the top part of a list of pricing steps.

Learn more here:

  • Documentation: Sales Order Summary.

 

SAP Concur

The new Concur Travel experience makes it much easier to book travel involving multiple bookings, such as a flight plus hotel plus rental car. And if you just need to book one item, you can do that very easily now with the new Booking Agent powered by Joule.

New Concur Travel Experience

When travelling for a few days, one often needs to book more than one item. A typical combination is booking a flight, a hotel and a rental car. Up until now, you have had to book each item separately and take care that the dates and time match. Now, with the new Concur Travel experience, planning and booking is much easier: you can enter the start and end dates for your flight, and the new feature Match Flight Booking is applied to the hotel and car, so that dates and time match automatically.

Figures 7 to 11 show what this looks like: Figure 7 shows the start screen, where you select which items you want to include (flight, hotel, car, train). Figure 8 shows the flight view, where flight dates have been entered. Figure 9 shows the hotel search, with the default selection “Based on flight selection”, and similarly Figure 10 shows the rental car search, with pick-up and return times calculated based on the flight schedule. Figure 11 shows the finalize screen, in this case showing that the flight and hotel has been selected but the rental car is still open.

Figure 7: New Concur Travel experience start screen. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over with a large image of a magnifying glass on a globe, above the text “Start Planning”. Below that four check boxes in a row: Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train, at the bottom “Continue” and “Cancel” buttons.

Figure 8: New Concur Travel experience screen with flight details. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a trip planning for a Trip to Las Vegas. The left third of the screen shows a list with items Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, with Flight selected. Below the list buttons “Add to trip” and “Search”. On the right a selector for round-trip (selected), one-way or multi-city, with fields for from / to locations and a date field for the stard and end date. To the right a button “Time preferences” and a drop-down for selecting “Cabin”.

Figure 9: New Concur Travel experience screen with hotel details. Alt Text: As for Figure 8, but with Hotel selected, and on the right Hotel Search displayed, with the fields for “Hotel, location, or name” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection”.

 Figure 10: New Concur Travel experience screen with rental car details. Alt Text: As for Figure 9, but with Rental Car selected, and on the right Rental Car Search displayed, with the fields for “Pickup” and “Dates” filled with the text “Based on flight selection” and the field “Drop-off” filled with “Same as pickup”. Pickup Time and Drop-off Time fields have 10:00 AM entered.

Figure 11: New Concur Travel experience finalize screen. Alt Text: Screenshot showing “Trip to Las Vegas” on the left two-thirds, with a card summarizing the flight with United Airlines from San Antonio, TX (SAT) – Las Vegas, NV (LAS) and a card summarizing the hotel Courtyard by Marriott Las Vegas. The right third shows the Estimated Total Cost $2497.85 above a list with the cost of each item (flight, hotel, rental car), and buttons for “Finalize Trip” and “Cancel Trip”, and options to book anything else (Flight, Hotel, Rental Car, Train).

As you can see in Figure 11, another advantage of the new experience is that you get budget transparency at the trip level. Also, you have flexibility to book parts of the travel now and other parts later.

Technically it supports deep linking, which means that you can send a trip-level link to colleagues which includes all the trip parts, making it easy to coordinate trip planning when travelling with others.

To find out more, have a look at the

  • Documentation: Trip Planning in New Concur Travel.

Booking Agent in Concur Travel

The new Booking Agent lets you use natural language to book business travel which is compliant with company policy and budget constraints as well as taking into account your personal travel preferences.

Figure 12 shows an example where the user has simply stated “I want to book a flight from San Francisco to London on Sept 9th and back on Sept 13th”. The answer shown takes into account the user’s frequent traveler memberships, flight availability and company policies.

Figure 12: New Concur Travel Booking Agent in Joule. Alt Text: A screenshot of Concur Travel with Joule opened on the right, the content is explained in the main text, with the possible flights listed alongside a thumbnail image representing the airline “jetBlue”.

Watch it in action and find out more:

  • Video: Concur Travel – Booking Agent demo (2:33 min.)
  • SAP Discovery Center: Booking Agent.

 

Continued soon…

I hope you enjoyed this sixth part, covering SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur, with great new AI-powered user experiences helping users work more efficiently and effectively.

The final part seven is coming later this week, covering latest innovations in UI technologies.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: VFX3 display billing amount
entry.content:
Unfortunately, VFX3 does not show the billing amount by default, and the standard layout doesn’t include that field. You need to go with developing the ALV layout either via User Exit or BAdI

You can work with your technical team to enhance the ALV grid using a user exit or BAdI (e.g., SDVFX) to include the billing amount field. This involves fetching the amount from VBRK-NETWR to fetch the total amount per billing document and injecting it into the ALV structure. Join VBRK with the billing document number (VBRK-VBELN) that’s already present in VFX3’s internal table. Inject the value into the ALV structure via enhancement or user exit. This ensures you're showing the correct total and avoids the complexity of summing multiple VBRP entries.

entry.title: Re: Is possible to use Tricentis Tosca in SAP CALM?
entry.content:
Hi LucasBeccon,

Yes, it is possible to use Tricentis Tosca with SAP Cloud ALM. SAP provides a smooth, one-click integration between Tricentis and SAP Cloud ALM, enabling customers to leverage powerful test automation capabilities directly within their ALM processes.

SAP Cloud ALM is the new ALM product offering from SAP, designed to support the move from on-premise to cloud. As part of this shift, SAP announced that mainstream support for CBTA will end after 2027. To ensure customers continue to have strong test automation options, SAP partnered with Tricentis.

Additionally, Tricentis can also integrate with SAP Solution Manager for customers who are still using on-premise solutions.

For more details, you can refer to:

  • Tricentis Test Automation for SAP in SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP ALM Partners – Test Automation

Thanks,

Nilabh

entry.title: Re: Facing issue while assigning automated test cases fro...
entry.content:
Hi SAPSupport,

To assign test cases from Tricentis Test Automation (TTA) to a Test Plan in your SAP Cloud ALM project, you'll first need to ensure the test cases are properly imported and synchronized with SAP Cloud ALM.

This process is handled via the Test Preparation app in SAP Cloud ALM. Within this app, you’ll find dedicated actions to:

  • Import test cases from TTA
  • Synchronize any updates or changes to those test cases

Once imported, the test cases will be available for assignment to your Test Plan within the project.

For a complete step-by-step guide, please refer to SAP Knowledge Base Article 3598767 — it covers the integration and synchronization process in detail.

If you've already connected TTA with SAP Cloud ALM, this setup allows for seamless orchestration and traceability of your automated tests directly from Cloud ALM.

Let me know if you'd like help navigating the Test Preparation app or configuring the test plan!

 

Thanks,

Nilabh

entry.title: Batch Determination Not Triggering in MIGO 261 but Works in Production Order Backflush
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am facing an issue with batch determination during goods issue for a production order.

Requirement: Batch determination should happen during goods issue (movement type 261) for both backflush and non-backflush components against a Production Order.

Current Situation:

  • I have set up the required batch determination configuration at Inventory Management level for movement type 261.

  • During production order confirmation with backflush (CO11N/CO15), batch determination works correctly and proposes batches automatically for the components.

  • However, during a manual goods issue in MIGO with movement type 261, batch determination does not trigger for the components and I need to enter the batches manually.

Could you please advise if I am missing any important configuration or additional steps to achieve this?

Thanks in advance,


Varun.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ALM and Tricentis TTA - SAP Standard Test s...
entry.content:
Hi SAPSupport,

When working with Tricentis Test Automation (TTA) integrated with SAP Cloud ALM, it’s important to distinguish between what’s available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Public Edition – Pre-Built Content Available

For the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are pre-delivered automated test scenarios. These are part of the "Test Automation Tool" specifically designed for the public cloud and are based on the SAP Best Practices from the SAP Activate Roadmap. These pre-built tests can be imported and orchestrated via SAP Cloud ALM — helping customers get started with test automation quickly and efficiently.

Private Edition – Custom Automation with Tricentis TTA

For the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, there is no out-of-the-box pre-packaged test content available at this time — either from SAP Cloud ALM or within Tricentis Test Automation. However, this doesn't limit your ability to automate:

  • You can build your own tailored test scenarios in Tricentis TTA, including support for SAP GUI, Fiori, and custom applications.
  • Once created, these test cases can be synchronized with SAP Cloud ALM.
  • SAP Cloud ALM then allows you to orchestrate test runs and gain centralized test reporting and traceability.

While it's a more hands-on approach in the Private Edition, the benefit is a fully customizable and scalable test automation framework tailored to your specific landscape and processes.

Looking Ahead

Tricentis and SAP continuously evolve their toolsets. While pre-packaged tests aren't currently available for Private Edition, the integration already provides a robust platform for end-to-end test automation and governance—and future content packs or accelerators may become available as the ecosystem matures.

 

Thanks,

Nilabh

entry.title: Re: Support Request: Realignment Process Issue Leading to...
entry.content:
The error message which you shared is typically points to a data overflow issue, where a field in the underlying program or structure is unable to accommodate the size or precision of the values being processed.

Check the below likely root causes

  • Each realignment may be creating new postings or adjusting existing ones. If the same document is realigned multiple times, it could result in cumulative values that exceed the field length (e.g., currency amounts or quantity fields).
  • The error suggests that a calculation field (likely in a structure used by FAGLL03) is not sized appropriately to handle the data. This could be due to a mismatch between Group Reporting ledger values and GL line item display logic.
  • Realignment may have introduced inconsistent or duplicate entries in the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) or Group Reporting Preparation Ledger (GRPL). FAGLL03 might be trying to calculate totals or balances that exceed expected limits.

Perform the below steps

  • Review the realignment version settings and ensure that the same documents are not being realigned repeatedly without reversal. If needed, reverse previous realignment runs before executing a new one.
  • Try running FAGLL03 with limited selection criteria (e.g., specific company code, document number, or posting date) to isolate the problematic entry.
  • Use SE16N or CDS views to inspect the ACDOCA entries for the affected documents. Look for unusually large values or duplicate postings.
  • Last but not least, still if your error is not resolved, this error may require a code-level fix or note from SAP.  So, raise a ticket to SAP, include the exact error message, dump ID (from ST22), and details of the realignment runs in your support ticket.

entry.title: Re: TTA for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Hi Rayane,

  • Predefined Test Scripts in TTA:
    Currently, there are no predefined (ready-to-use) test scripts available within Tricentis Test Automation for SAP (TTA). You will not find pre-delivered scripts inside TTA itself.
  • Using SAP Best Practices for Automatic Script Creation:
    Direct import of SAP Best Practice process models into TTA to automatically generate executable scripts is not supported. However, you can leverage SAP Cloud ALM’s process models (including SAP Best Practices content) as a reference and then design your test cases in TTA based on these models.
  • Creating Test Scripts in TTA:
    If predefined content is not available, you need to create your test scripts from scratch in TTA. The advantage is that TTA allows you to build modular test steps and reusable components, making script creation and maintenance easier over time.
  • Tricentis Licenses in SAP Cloud ALM:
    Yes, currently SAP Cloud ALM provides five included Tricentis Test Automation licenses per tenant. These licenses are intended for productive use, with limitations on the number of users who can design and execute automated test cases simultaneously. If additional capacity is required, customers can extend their licenses directly with Tricentis.

Thanks,

Nilabh

entry.title: Re: With how many recording licenses does TTA come with?
entry.content:
Hi Justin,

When you use Tricentis Test Automation (TTA) through SAP Cloud ALM, it includes 5 named user licenses for test creation and execution — often referred to as “recording licenses.”

These licenses are:

  • Provided at no additional cost as part of your SAP Cloud ALM entitlement
  • Intended for test designers and automation engineers to create, edit, and maintain automated test cases
  • Tied to named users, meaning each license is assigned to a specific individual

If your testing needs go beyond the 5 included licenses, you would need to engage with SAP or Tricentis to explore additional licensing options based on your project scope.

Thanks,

Nilabh

entry.title: Re: How to find the line items that made up settlement? T...
entry.content:
To be honest, I don't have patience to go through all your coding lines but let me try to explain the logic which might address your requirement.

The Key to Distribution Rules of COBRB is it stores settlement rules for internal orders and other CO objects. It includes:

  • OBJNR: Object number (e.g., internal order)
  • PERBZ: Settlement type (e.g., periodic, full)
  • PROZS: Percentage for settlement
  • BETRR: Amount for amount-based rules
  • PS_PSP_PNR: WBS element (receiver)
  • AUFNR: Order number (sender)
  • GJAHR / PERIO: Validity period

SAP uses these rules during settlement (e.g., via transaction KO88) to distribute costs from sender to receiver. If you're joining your source data to COBRB, you can apply the percentage logic to split the amounts accordingly. Importantly, SAP rounds percentages to 3 decimals internally, but the actual distribution may involve equivalence numbers (AQZIF) or remaining amount logic (BREST). These can cause minor rounding differences that are hard to trace.

So you can try the below approach

  • COBRA contains settlement document metadata — useful for linking to the actual settlement run.
  • If you want to trace back to the original postings, COEP (CO line items) is your best friend. It contains OBJNR, BELNR, BUZEI, VRGNG, WRTTP, BEKNZ. You can filter by VRGNG = 'SETT' and BEKNZ ≠ 'A' to isolate relevant lines.
  • If you're on S/4HANA, SAP provides CDS views like I_ActualCOLineItemCube that simplify access to COEP and related tables.

So in short,

entry.title: Re: Batch Determination Not Triggering in MIGO 261 but Wo...
entry.content:
To clarify your doubt "why batch determination doesn’t trigger in MIGO (261)", unlike CO11N/CO15, which are tightly integrated with Production Order logic, MIGO is a general-purpose inventory transaction. That means:

  • Batch determination is not triggered automatically in MIGO unless explicitly invoked.
  • MIGO does not inherently apply the same search strategy logic unless the user manually activates it.

Try with the below approaches

  • In MIGO, after entering the material and movement type 261, click the “Stock Determination” button (usually found near the batch field). This manually triggers batch determination using the strategy you've configured. Please note, if you enter * in the batch field and press Enter, SAP may also trigger batch determination; but this depends on your system version and configuration.
  • Ensure the following are correctly configured in SPRO → Logistics General → Batch Management → Batch Determination and Batch Check:

If you are new to SAP, use the below transactions:

  • OMJJ to confirm movement type settings
  • MBC1 to assign strategy
  • MBC2 to define strategy type

entry.title: SAP Field Logistics: Next Generation Kitting & Staging for MRO Industries
entry.content:
For any MRO organization (Maintenance, Repair, and Operations), kitting and staging is a core warehouse activity. On the surface, it seems simple. But in reality, it's a web of complexity, often managed by years of accumulated custom code and custom business process. 

Introducing Standard Kitting & Staging in S/4HANA 2023

With the release of S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, the struggle with custom kitting solutions is over. SAP has delivered a standard, industry-focused solution designed specifically for the intricacies of MRO: End-to-End Kitting & Staging with SAP Field Logistics.

This solution was co-designed with customers to address the real-world challenges you face every day. It’s built on six core principles to deliver a unified, streamlined process.

1. Centralize Kitting for Remote Operations Efficiently to build, stage, and dispatch kits from a central warehouse directly to remote or field locations, ensuring the right parts are in the right place at the right time.

2. Handle All Types of Goods Seamlessly Support not only inventory managed materials, but also non inventory stock, rental equipment and supplier provided items as part of services, ensuring full visibility and control across all goods movements

3. Empower Your Field Locations Don’t just ship parts—ship capability. Remote sites can now receive kits, manage kits, add locally held components, and issue the completed kit directly to a maintenance order.

4. Simplify and Standardize Your Processes Whether you operate a single, streamlined plant or manage a complex network of remote locations supported by a supply base, this solution provides a standard, repeatable process to eliminate guesswork and create one version of the truth for your kitting and staging operations.

5. Gain End-to-End Visibility in a Single Place Stop chasing information across different systems. The entire kitting lifecycle—from creation and staging to dispatch and final issuance—is tracked in a single, accessible repository, giving you unprecedented control and insight. 

6. Scale for Your Environment This isn't a rigid, one-size-fits-all tool. The solution is designed to scale and adapt, supporting various warehouse management setups including Inventory Management (IM), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), and even hybrid combinations depending on your organisation.

A Future-Proof Foundation for Your MRO Warehouse

By embedding this critical MRO process directly into the S/4HANA core, SAP has delivered a solution that is robust, scalable, and future proof. You can finally retire that aging custom code, move forward with confidence using a standard SAP solution at the base.

This is more than just a new feature; it's a new foundation for operational excellence in your MRO supply chain.

From Order to Staged Kit: A Look at the New Process

So, how does it actually work? The entire process is designed to be intuitive and integrated with maintenance and project business process.  And it all begins exactly where it should: with the demand from the field. 

Step 1: The Kit is Born from the Demand Signal It all starts with a Work Order or Network Order; the kit is automatically created and updated. As the requested materials arrive at the Supply Base, using the Field Logistics Cross-Docking process, the system automatically triggers the tracking milestones and begins the process of bringing everything together.

What truly sets this solution apart is its flexibility in defining the kit. You are no longer locked into a single method like in the past. At the demand plant level, you can define a kit based:

  • The Work Order/Network Order Header: Perfect for bundling all materials where work is planned and scheduled at the header.
  • A Work Order/Network Order Operation: Ideal for creating kits for specific phases or tasks within a more detailed planning and scheduling environment. 
  • A flexible definition via BAdI: For unique business requirements, this allows you to implement custom logic while remaining within the standard framework.

Step 2: Augment the Kit with Local Inventory The process doesn't stop with the initial cross dock. If required, you can easily supplement the base kit by adding stock directly from local base inventory or as more cross docking occurs. This hybrid approach allows you to combine centrally sourced materials with locally available parts for maximum efficiency, speed and tracking.

Step 3: Pack, Stage, and Track with Precision Once complete, the kit can be packed into standard Field Logistics objects like Containers or Packages.

Crucially, every object—including the delivery items —can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field via the Pack Containers (F5786)app. This eliminates guesswork and "lost" kits. The result is pinpoint accuracy on the warehouse floor, where everyone knows exactly what a kit contains, where it is, and which job it’s for.

Flexibility at the Edge: Managing Kits Upon Arrival

The journey doesn't end when the kit leaves the central warehouse. A core strength of SAP Field Logistics is its ability to track the Supply Chain end to end. The solution is designed to handle several common scenarios:

Scenario 1: The "Base Kit" Handover

In this model, all components have been kitted at the central base. The kit arrives at the remote location fully prepared. The process here is built for speed and simplicity:

  • Receive: The remote site performs a simple goods receipt for the complete kit.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 2: The "Remote Kit" Assembly

This scenario is common in industries like Mining or Land-Based Operations where remote sites are highly self-sufficient. Here, no physical goods are shipped from the base. Instead:

  • Demand Signal: The demand is to be supplied fully from the remote site.
  • Local Assembly: The kit is assembled and managed entirely at the remote location using its locally held inventory. This empowers the remote team to take full ownership of the kitting process and support the operations stocking strategy.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 3: The "Re-Kit" Hybrid Model

This flexible, hybrid approach offers the best of both worlds. A base kit containing centrally sourced or specialized parts is shipped from the main warehouse. Upon arrival:

  • Receive Base Kit: The initial kit is received at the remote location.
  • Augment Locally: The remote team then adds further components to the kit directly from their local inventory to create the final package.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

This adaptability—from a simple handover to full remote assembly—ensures that no matter your operational model, the system supports your reality on the ground.

Mastering "The Last Mile": Detailed Tracking at the Remote Site

The final journey of a kit—from the remote warehouse shelf to the hands of a technician—is often a logistical black box. This critical phase, aptly named "The Last Mile," is where parts get misplaced, jobs get delayed, and efficiency breaks down. A common problem is the lack of real-time visibility once a kit is "in the system" but not yet in use.

SAP Field Logistics solves this by introducing key tracking milestones for the entire "Last Mile" lifecycle. Now, users can pinpoint exactly where everything is in real-time.

1. Stage - Once a kit item is received or assembled at the remote location, its status is set to Staged. It is officially logged as staged and ready for the job. The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin using a dedicated standard field. The warehouse knows exactly what is ready and precisely where to find it.

2. Drop - As the job start time approaches, the kit needs to move closer to the point of work. When this happens, its status is updated to Dropped. It can then be assigned to a nominated drop point—like a specific laydown yard or workshop area—again using a dedicated standard location field.

3. Issue - This is the final, crucial handover. The kits items status is updated to Issued at the moment the technician formally receives the complete kit. This closes the loop on the logistics process, providing a clear and simple audit trail. It confirms that the right parts were delivered to the right person at the right time, minimizing disputes and ensuring the job can begin without delay.

Unlocking Total Visibility: Answering "Where Is My Stuff?"

In any MRO operation, the question "Where is my stuff?" is asked daily. But "stuff" can mean anything—an individual component, a complex kit for a shutdown, or all the materials for a week's worth of routine maintenance. Answering this question accurately and in real-time has always been a major challenge.

SAP Field Logistics answers this question by tracking every item against extensive, standard milestones, it provides a single source of truth. This critical information is no longer buried in spreadsheets or system tables; it is visualized in intuitive Fiori applications and via exposed API's.

While day-to-day operations are handled in the Manage Kits (F8005) and Manage Logistics (F5082) apps, the consolidated view of this new visibility comes to life in the Logistics Tracking (F7382) app.

First delivered with S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, the Logistics Tracking App has now been specifically enhanced to include the key kitting milestones. This means the "Last Mile" statuses—Stage, Drop, and Issue—are now surfaced directly in this central dashboard.

The result is a single view where planners, supervisors, and technicians can see the real-time status of any component or kit, from the central warehouse all the way to the point of use. The question is no longer "Where is my stuff?" but "What do I need to look at next?"

Five Core Capabilities That Transform MRO Logistics

Having walked through the end-to-end process, from the central warehouse to the final handover, we can see how SAP Field Logistics delivers a set of transformative capabilities that directly address the core challenges of MRO supply chains.

1. A Single, Standardized Process from Warehouse to Worksite For the first time, a single, standard process governs the entire kitting lifecycle. From the initial build in a supply base to augmenting a kit at a remote site and issuing it to a technician, the system provides one unified framework. This eliminates process variations, reduces training overhead, and establishes a foundation for operational excellence across the entire organization.

2. Real-Time, End-to-End Visibility The question "Where is my stuff?" is definitively answered. Through the Logistics Tracking App and dedicated Fiori dashboards, you have a single source of truth. By tracking key milestones like Staged, Dropped, and Issued, you gain complete, real-time visibility into the "Last Mile," enabling better decision-making and proactive control.

3. Flexibility for Real-World Operations This is not a rigid, one-size-fits-all solution. It is built to adapt to your reality. Whether you need to define a kit by an entire work order or a specific operation, or whether you manage kits centrally, remotely, or through a hybrid model, the solution provides the flexibility to support your specific business needs.  For example - your operation does not drop but issues directly from staging, this is supported.

4. Integration with Core Maintenance and Warehouse Processes SAP Field Logistics is not a standalone module; it is woven into the digital core. It integrates seamlessly with Maintenance Orders, Network Orders, Logistics Execution (LE), Inventory Management (IM), and Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). This ensures data consistency, prevents information silos, and creates a smooth, automated flow from maintenance planning to field execution.

5. Finally Retire Custom Code and Embrace a Clean Core Perhaps the most strategic benefit is the ability to finally retire your expensive, high-risk custom kitting solutions. By moving this critical functionality into the S/4HANA standard, you can eliminate technical debt, simplify future upgrades, and fully embrace a "clean core" strategy. This reduces your total cost of ownership and positions your organization on a future-proof platform for years to come.

Conclusion: The Future is Standard

For years, managing MRO kitting has meant a compromise. Organizations were forced to choose between a standard SAP process that didn't fully meet their needs or investing heavily in complex, custom-coded solutions that created technical debt and upgrade risk. These "Z-solutions," while functional, were brittle, expensive to maintain, and operated in a silo with each customer to define everything including integration.

With the introduction of SAP Field Logistics in S/4HANA, that era is over.

The journey from a fragmented, high-maintenance custom process to a powerful, flexible, and standard solution is no longer a future ambition—it is a present reality. We have seen how Field Logistics provides a single, unified framework to:

  • Define and build kits with flexibility.
  • Manage them across diverse remote site scenarios.
  • Track them through "The Last Mile."
  • Visualize their status in real-time for all stakeholders.

This is more than a new module; it is a fundamental shift in strategy. It is the opportunity to finally retire your custom code, shed decades of technical debt, and embrace a "clean core" architecture. It's a chance to align your operations with a future-proof platform that will evolve with your business, not hold it back.

The path forward is no longer about building a better workaround; it's about leveraging a better standard. The future of MRO logistics isn't custom; it's standard.

For further details on Field Logistics, relevent Other Blogs, Roadmap and Important Notes:

  • SAP Field Logistics: Enhancing Rental Onboarding and Monitoring through SAP Fieldglass Integration
  • SAP Field Logistics: Centralized Supplier Item Repository for an Optimized Rental Process

  • Manage Kits - https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/0f4ab800d01c4366b0c9aaff06a64320/ece58095935e4354a19ad4b071f85160.html?locale=en-US&version=2023.latest
  • Logistics Tracking - https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/0f4ab800d01c4366b0c9aaff06a64320/b2aeba198dee46f281d3e4456cc1836e.html?locale=en-US&version=2023.latest

entry.title: Accelerating Test Automation with Tricentis in SAP Cloud ALM Projects
entry.content:
Introduction:

Enable Continuous Quality in Implementation and Operations with Seamless Integration

In today's fast-paced digital landscape, SAP customers are expected to deliver high-quality releases quickly while ensuring system stability. Whether it’s an S/4HANA Cloud implementation or continuous delivery in a RISE with SAP journey, the need for intelligent, automated testing is no longer optional — it’s essential.

This is where Tricentis Tosca and SAP Cloud ALM come together as a powerful duo to enable end-to-end test automation across the lifecycle.

 

Connecting Tricentis Tosca with SAP Cloud ALM

SAP Cloud ALM offers out-of-the-box integration with Tricentis Test Automation tools, including Tricentis Tosca. This allows project teams to trigger and monitor automated tests directly from SAP Cloud ALM, without switching between tools.

Integration Highlights:

SAP Cloud ALM provides a Test Automation Framework (TAF) which connects to Tosca via API-based communication.

Once integrated, test cases created in Tosca are mapped to Cloud ALM test cases.

Test execution can be scheduled or triggered via test plans or change processes in Cloud ALM.

Results are automatically synchronized, enabling traceability and centralized reporting.

The setup is streamlined with guided configuration steps provided in the SAP help portal and Tricentis documentation — making the integration accessible even for first-time users.

Why Model-Based Test Automation?

Tricentis Tosca uses model-based testing, which means it relies on business-readable models instead of scripts. This is particularly effective for SAP environments, where frequent changes in UI and custom developments make script-based automation brittle.

Benefits for SAP projects:

  • Reduced maintenance effort: UI changes don’t break the tests.
  • Faster test creation: Business users can help define test cases.
  • Reusable modules: Build once, use across multiple processes and projects.
  • End-to-end coverage: Supports both SAP and non-SAP systems, including APIs, web apps, and legacy systems.

Use Cases: Implementation vs Operations

SAP Cloud ALM supports test orchestration for both Implementation and Operations phases, and Tricentis Tosca plays a key role in both:

During Implementation Projects:

  • Automate unit and integration testing of configured or customized processes.
  • Validate fit-to-standard processes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  • Use Tosca to test Fiori apps, custom code, and interfaces during rollouts.
  • Integrate tests with change documents in Cloud ALM for full traceability.

During Operations (Run Phase):

  • Schedule automated regression tests after system updates or hotfixes.
  • Monitor and validate critical business processes continuously.
  • Use automation to validate incident resolutions or changes in the landscape.

Real-World Example: S/4HANA Cloud Transformation

Let’s take a common scenario: A customer is transitioning to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition. The implementation includes custom forms, new workflows, and several integration points.

With Tricentis Tosca and SAP Cloud ALM:

  • The team automates test cases for the Sales Order Creation process, covering Fiori screens, email workflows, and third-party logistics interfaces.
  • These tests are triggered via Cloud ALM whenever a transport is moved or a sprint is completed.
  • Upon a quarterly upgrade from SAP, regression testing is completed in hours — not days — ensuring business continuity.

Result? Faster deployments, fewer errors, and higher confidence in every change.

Conclusion:

Bringing Intelligence to SAP Testing

Automated testing is no longer a luxury; it is a foundation of agile and resilient SAP projects. By integrating Tricentis Tosca with SAP Cloud ALM, organizations can:

  • Shift left and test early
  • Automate end-to-end business processes
  • Reduce test effort and cost
  • Improve go-live success and operational stability

As you scale your SAP landscape with SAP Cloud ALM, adding Tricentis to your toolbox enables continuous quality at speed — a key driver of digital transformation.
